results.title: Bhaji on the beach
results.creator_credit: Umbi Films, Nadine Marsh-Edwards and Gurinder Chadha
results.brief_description: Life for 10 Anglo-Indian women from the industrial city of Birmingham is about to take a decidedly interesting turn. They’ve set off on a bus trip to the seaside resort of Blackpool for a “female fun time”. With a mixed bag of ages, attitudes and social classes, it’s going to be nothing short of outrageous when these ladies leave behind the demands of spoiled husbands, children and lovers to encounter a world full of strippers, seducers and several other british unmentionables!

results.title: Bezin lug = Bezhin meadow
results.brief_description:
Bezhin Meadow’ is a reconstruction, using photographs, of a lost, unfinished Eisenstein film from 1935-37. It is set against the background of the collectivisation of agriculture and based on a true story of the death of a young pioneer whose father considered him to be an enemy of his class. Also available on VHS.

Credits: Director, Sergei Eisenstein ; photography, E. Tisse. Note: ‘Bezhin Meadow’ reconstructed in 1968 by Sergei Yutkevich and Naum Kleimann with music by Sergei Prokofiev

results.title: Bezhin Meadow = Bezhin Lug
results.brief_description: Introduced in English. Eisenstein’s “Bezhin Meadow” was to be a drama set against the background of collectivisation of agriculture and based on the true story of Pavlick Morosov, a little boy who organised his fellow pioneers to guard the harvest so effectively that his own Kulak family, planning sabotage, felt him an enemy of his class and killed him. The result can only be a shadow; but this 1966 half hour reconstruction has a force which makes one regret bitterly what must have been Eisenstein’s finest film. From a story by Ivan Turgenev.

results.title: Beyond therapy
results.creator_credit: New World Pictures, Roger Berlind, Sandcastle 5, Steven Haft and Robert Altman
results.brief_description: Prudence (Julie Hagerty) is a conservative and slightly mixed-up young woman who thinks Bruce (Jeff Goldblum) is crazy. Bruce is crazy about Prudence, despite the fact that he is bisexual. Their therapists are no better off. Prudence’s therapist (Tom Conti) is more interested in scoring with his female patients than in treating their problems. Bruce’s therapist is as flighty as they come. Throw in Bruce’s jealous lover Bob (Christopher Guest), and his overly protective mother, and the scene is set for madness and mayhem. Adapted from his Broadway play by screenwriter Christopher Durang.

results.title: Beyond the wall
results.creator_credit: Nomad Films International and Ronald Branscombe
results.brief_description: Takes a look at the semi-nomadic herding economy of the people of inner Mongolia whom still mantain their ancient culture despite the intrusion of the modern world. Shows the division of labour, the importance of the horse to the community and the men’s superb horsemanship, constant search for water, types of food eaten and the traditional customs followed at a marriage ceremony. Also notes how the introduction of regular schooling and health care improved general standards of living and young people living an urban lifestyle unknown to their parents.

results.title: Beyond the volta
results.creator_credit: Gold Coast Film Unit and Enoch Vander Pule
results.brief_description: Discusses the economic and political progress of a region in West Africa now known as Trans-Volta Togoland. Points out that once local government was set up, steps were taken to provide the region with a system of roads and bridges, and adequate water supply and hospitals and clinics to help in the fight against leprosy and other diseases prevelant in tropical countries. Advances in industrial and agricultural fields were also made; these included re-establishment of the palm oil industry and the introduction of modern methods and machinery. Progress is being made in the educational field by the establishment of technical colleges and universities.

results.title: Beyond the valley of the dolls
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Russ Meyer
results.brief_description: Independent maverick, Russ Meyer, renowned for low-budget, transgressive porn and exploitation cinema, made his first studio film with “Beyond the valley of the dolls”. Teaming up with screenwriter Roger Ebert, today one of America’s most influential film critics, Meyer loosely based the film on the earlier “Valley of the dolls” (Mark Robson, 1967). An ambitious, uninhibited, all-girls rock band, starring Kelly (Dolly Read), Casey (Cynthia Myers), and Pet (Marcia McBroom), travel to L.A. with their manager, Harris (David Gurian), to visit Kelly’s aunt and claim an inheritance. A glamorous and successful woman in showbiz, Aunt Susan (Phyllis Davis), introduces the girls to producer and promoter, Z-Man (played superbly by John Lazar), who eventually leads them to phenomenal success. A sheer highlight of the film is the party sequence where the girls are introduced to this heady, topsy-turvy, circus-like world. Despite the surface frivolity, however, melodrama, horror, violence, and life-learning lessons await the three girls. Punchy dialogue, snappy editing, and great music make “Beyond the valley of the dolls” an entertaining film. And like exploitation cinema, often the corny plot lines and developments are fill-ins for outrageous visual action and energy. However, though its uninhibited attitude toward sex, nudity, and drug taking keeps it in line with hippy culture and exploitation cinema, the film’s moralistic finale and condemnation of non-heterosexual desire makes it conservative and a world away from the true values of the counter-culture.
